head.title: Midwest to New York: Think Before Asking

hedline.hl1: Midwest to New York: Think Before Asking

block.p: Much more important events have been on all of our minds in the last 10 days, but I am commenting now on "America's Duty to New York; Fighting for Fairness: I" (editorial, Jan. 6).

You suggest that Congress should spread the burden of your needy residents among suburbanites and Midwest farmers. I am a Midwesterner and do live on a farm, but am not a real farmer. Your conclusion may indeed be correct. What is "wrong" is the clear image that Midwesterners, agribusiness people and otherwise, have of the New York milieu.

The day after your editorial appeared a lead article in The Wall Street Journal cited a young investment banker who made $23 million last year; a few days later there was mention of another who made $20 million. The obscene incomes of the Boesky-Milken era may be behind us, but the image sticks.

I know of no Iowa farmers who make incomes anything like that and doubt if there are more than a handful with seven-figure incomes. When they were suffering from the malaise of the early 80's (and drought in the late 80's) they did not seek -- or expect -- New Yorkers to come to their rescue.

There is a different mind-set out here; different values pervade the landscape. Your editorial writers -- as well as your politicians -- would do well to spend some time with people for whom $20 million incomes are the stuff of "Bonfire" and "Wall Street." You may be right, but you have a long way to go to convince people in rural Dubuque, Durham and Duncan to help. RICHARD KOLCK Dubuque, Iowa, Jan. 15, 1991
